I don't like how especially Jimmy conflates being accused of and being 
guilty of domestic violence. That's not to say that I think there are tons 
of people accusing their partners of domestic violence, but I still think 
he shouldn't act as smug as he does – after all, TYT are on the front of 
telling us how important innocent until proven guilty and due process are, 
and rightfully so!
About the law itself: it definitely makes a lot of sense. I do see two 
potential flaws though. One is that I do suppose there will be a gender 
bias, that is if a man accuses a woman of domestic violence, the judge will 
be a lot more likely to not confiscate her weapons.
The other is as follows: although it's, I suppose, only a small part of a 
percent, there will be persons wrongfully accusing their spouses of 
domestic violence. Now that wouldn't be much of a problem itself. However, 
my feeling is that those persons (who wrongfully accuse their spouses) are 
significally more likely to be erratic and dangerous themselves, and 
potentially also manipulative. So for this undoubtably small fraction of 
cases, the accuser could – deliberately or subconsciously – use this rule 
to get rid of their spouses guns and then assault them. The problem is that 
even though it only be very few cases, in those cases the consequences 
would be catastrophic. Since as John and Jimmy noted there's also the issue 
with the offender still having access to other types of weaponry, I think 
they should at least have two cops (or even better people who know how to 
de-escalate) escort the supposed victim when they fetch their stuff. That 
would improve safety for victims a lot, and might help detect the cases of 
abuse of this law (for instance if the escort witnesses the "victim" 
actively engaging in an argument while the "offender" acts passively).﻿

+FLCOM1 This bill addresses due process. In order for the guns to be 
confiscated, the person involved has to have a temporary restraining order

judges at preliminary hearings. Preliminary hearings are where a judge

where a judge would set the terms of bail, remand the defendant, etc. It 
all depends on the level of evidence at the time of the preliminary 
hearing. Taking away their guns is not a punitive measure, it's a 
precautionary decision made by a judge based on the evidence available at 
the time, no different than if a judge decided that it was too risky for 
the defendant to be let out on bail or if the judge decided that a 
restraining order was necessary (like they would have to anyway for this 
law to apply).

there are roughly 3,200 defensive uses of firearms in the US annually. Not 
all of those are going to be successful uses, but for the sake of the

+Erik Dumas Animation the right to bear arms has no limits, in fact it

cup of coffee, I shall go to the store." Can logically assume that I will

but the previous clause not withstanding, the right to keep and bear shall 
not be infringed.

+Michael P I wish I could pull up more stats, but there aren't many to 
begin with. In my research, though, I did learn something similar to what 
this law is proposing is happening.

When potential domestic abusers are arrest, the potential victim is usually 
granted a restraining order against the arrested. Sometimes this entails 
more stringent measures, sometimes it does not. 

If I remember the facts correctly, a gun can be taken from the accused if 
that particular person has a history of violence or if the evidence of 
violence inflicted on the victim is substantial. The issue arises when the 
police enforcing the restraining order doesn't complete the whole of the 
conditions, whether by forgetfulness or misinformation. This was pretty 
surprising to me since I thought the CT legislators were trying to fill in 
a gap that didn't exist at all.

I think that if more people knew about the provisions that can be added to 
a restraining order issued in these cases, then more judges would consider 
the option depending on the circumstances and the police would actively 
look if there is such a provision in the fine text. 

I try not to put that much faith in "good guys with guns" since there are 
many well intention people who haven't had the training to properly use a 
gun, which increases the potential for collateral damage. Not to mention 
the situation if police misidentify him as one of the suspects on the scene.

The slippery slope argument is a flawed one, in that if you change a law 
and then someone wants to change a law again to go further with it than the 
last one the whole process has to start again from the beginning. Support 
needs to be gathered, people need to be convinced, politicians need to vote 
a majority in favour of it (often in two legislative chambers) and it would 
need to be reviewed again quite likely. There is no slippery slope, laws 
are almost set in stone until they are repealed or superseded if people 
think some new change goes too far they can change can decide not to 
support a change.﻿
